news_summary: Today's news highlights fascinating insights into animal cognition, the nuances of scientific communication, and the evolutionary adaptations of ancient predators.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité d'aujourd'hui met en lumière des aspects fascinants de la cognition animale, les nuances de la communication scientifique et les adaptations évolutives des anciens prédateurs.
news_summary_es: Las noticias de hoy destacan fascinantes descubrimientos sobre la cognición animal, los matices de la comunicación científica y las adaptaciones evolutivas de los antiguos depredadores.

articles.title: Octopuses fall for the rubber hand illusion just like us
articles.summary: Octopuses can be tricked into thinking that a fake arm is part of their body, suggesting they have a sense of body ownership similar to our own
articles.content:
Octopuses can be tricked into thinking that a fake arm is part of their body, suggesting they have a sense of body ownership similar to our own

Plain-body octopuses can be duped into thinking a fake arm is their own Sumire Kawashima and Yuzuru Ikeda/the University of the Ryukyus

Just like humans, octopuses can be fooled by an illusion that makes them think a fake arm is actually theirs.

First demonstrated in the late 1990s, the rubber hand illusion involves hiding a person’s real hand and placing a fake one on a table in front of them, then stroking both simultaneously. Later, it was found that other mammals, such as mice, can also be fooled by the same trick.

Advertisement

Now, Sumire Kawashima and Yuzuru Ikeda at the University of the Ryukyus in Okinawa, Japan, have discovered that octopuses are also vulnerable to the illusion.

For the study, captive plain-body octopuses (Callistoctopus aspilosomatis) were placed in an experimental tank. A fake octopus arm made of soft gel attached to an opaque partition was placed over one of the octopus’s arms, blocking its view of the real arm. Then one of the researchers used plastic callipers to stroke both the fake arm and the real arm at the same time.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

After about 8 seconds, the researcher pinched the fake arm with tweezers. All six of the octopuses that participated in 24 trials of this test exhibited defence responses, such as changing colour, retracting their arm or fleeing.

When the test was carried out with no stroking or with non-simultaneous stroking, or when the posture of the fake arm didn’t match that of the real arm, then the effect of the illusion disappeared.

In the experiment, the octopus could see a fake arm above a partition obscuring their real arm Sumire Kawashima and Yuzuru Ikeda/the University of the Ryukyus

The experiment demonstrates both a benefit and a flaw in the wiring of human and octopus brains, says Ikeda. “The illusion would suggest the ability for octopuses to anticipate and predict, which is advantageous for survival,” he says. “On the other hand, this ability arises as a side effect of a mistake or conflict of processing in the brain and is also a flaw.”

Kawashima says the study adds to the list of abilities that octopuses share with humans. “Our findings suggest the octopus may be an important model for studying the evolution of the sense of body ownership,” she says.

Peter Godfrey-Smith at the University of Sydney, Australia, says the results were unexpected for him. “It suggests that octopuses have quite a rich body image,” he says. “I am struck by the fact that the ‘posture incongruence’ condition worked as it did: the octopuses did not see the rubber arm as their own in that case, despite the stroking.”
articles.reasoning: This scientific discovery about octopuses sharing a sense of body ownership similar to humans is a positive advancement in understanding animal cognition and evolution. It highlights the complexity of octopus brains and opens new avenues for research, which can inspire curiosity and appreciation for animal intelligence.
articles.personality_title: Octopuses fooled by rubber hand illusion just like humans
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long studied how humans recognize their own bodies. One famous test, called the rubber hand illusion, tricks people into feeling that a fake hand is actually part of their body. Now, researchers wondered if octopuses, known for their smart and flexible brains, could experience this too.

**What happened**
Researchers showed that octopuses can be tricked by the rubber hand illusion. When a fake arm was moved in sync with the octopus’s hidden real arm, the octopus reacted as if the fake arm was its own. This means octopuses have a sense of body ownership similar to humans.

**Impact**
This discovery is exciting because it shows octopuses have a complex understanding of their own bodies. It opens up new ways to study how animals think and feel, helping us appreciate their intelligence and the amazing evolution of brains beyond mammals.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to explore how octopuses’ brains create this sense of self. Understanding this can reveal more about animal awareness and could even inspire better designs in robotics or prosthetics by mimicking octopus body control.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Octopuses share a surprising ability with humans to recognize their own body, showing just how smart and aware these sea creatures really are.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les pieuvres trompées par l'illusion de la main en caoutchouc comme les humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques ont longtemps étudié comment les humains reconnaissent leur propre corps. Un test célèbre, appelé illusion de la main en caoutchouc, fait croire aux gens qu'une fausse main fait partie de leur corps. Maintenant, les chercheurs se sont demandés si les pieuvres, connues pour leur cerveau intelligent et flexible, pouvaient aussi vivre cela.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont montré que les pieuvres peuvent être trompées par l’illusion de la main en caoutchouc. Quand un bras factice bougeait en même temps que le vrai bras caché de la pieuvre, celle-ci réagissait comme si le faux bras lui appartenait. Cela signifie que les pieuvres ont un sens de la propriété corporelle similaire à celui des humains.

**Impact**
Cette découverte est enthousiasmante car elle montre que les pieuvres ont une compréhension complexe de leur propre corps. Elle ouvre de nouvelles voies pour étudier la pensée et les émotions des animaux, nous aidant à mieux apprécier leur intelligence et l’évolution étonnante des cerveaux au-delà des mammifères.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’explorer comment le cerveau des pieuvres crée ce sens de soi. Comprendre cela peut révéler davantage sur la conscience animale et pourrait même inspirer de meilleures conceptions en robotique ou en prothèses en imitant le contrôle corporel des pieuvres.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Les pieuvres partagent une capacité surprenante avec les humains à reconnaître leur propre corps, montrant à quel point ces créatures marines sont intelligentes et conscientes.
articles.personality_title_es: Los pulpos engañados por la ilusión de la mano de goma como los humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han estudiado durante mucho tiempo cómo los humanos reconocen su propio cuerpo. Una prueba famosa, llamada la ilusión de la mano de goma, engaña a las personas para que sientan que una mano falsa es parte de su cuerpo. Ahora, los investigadores se preguntaron si los pulpos, conocidos por sus cerebros inteligentes y flexibles, también podían experimentar esto.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores demostraron que los pulpos pueden ser engañados por la ilusión de la mano de goma. Cuando un brazo falso se movía al mismo ritmo que el brazo real oculto del pulpo, este reaccionaba como si el brazo falso fuera suyo. Esto significa que los pulpos tienen un sentido de propiedad corporal similar al de los humanos.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento es emocionante porque muestra que los pulpos tienen una comprensión compleja de su propio cuerpo. Abre nuevas formas de estudiar cómo piensan y sienten los animales, ayudándonos a apreciar su inteligencia y la increíble evolución de cerebros más allá de los mamíferos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean investigar cómo el cerebro del pulpo crea este sentido del yo. Entender esto puede revelar más sobre la conciencia animal e incluso inspirar mejores diseños en robótica o prótesis al imitar el control corporal de los pulpos.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Los pulpos comparten una sorprendente habilidad con los humanos para reconocer su propio cuerpo, demostrando lo inteligentes y conscientes que son estas criaturas marinas.
articles.image_prompt: A warm and detailed painting of a curious octopus gently touching a soft, translucent rubbery arm floating above a calm ocean floor, with subtle ripples and muted natural tones highlighting the connection and playful illusion between the real and the fake limb.

articles.title: Scientific jargon can be ‘satisfying’ — but misleading
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 21 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02251-0Research shows that jargon can make weak explanations feel complete by masking their gaps. What can experts do to communicate science effectively to laypeople?
articles.content:
When scientists write for lay audiences, they face a familiar dilemma: should they use technical language that reflects precision and authority, or simpler language that maximizes clarity? In a study published in Nature Human Behaviour, Cruz and Lombrozo1 offer fresh insights into this communication dilemma. The paper shows that jargon has different effects on how readers perceive and understand explanations — and that these differences have consequences for both science consumers and science communicators.

Nature 643, 916-917 (2025)

doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-025-02251-0

References Cruz, F. & Lombrozo, T. Nature Hum. Behav. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-025-02227-0 (2025). Shulman, H. C., Markowitz, D. M. & Rogers, T. Sci. Adv. 10, eadn2555 (2024). Rogers, T. & Lasky-Fink, J. Writing for Busy Readers: Communicate More Effectively in the Real World (Dutton, 2023). Download references

Competing Interests The authors declare no competing interests.

Related Articles

Subjects
articles.reasoning: The article discusses new scientific insights into how jargon affects communication, which can help improve science communication to the public. While not a breakthrough or a direct benefit like a medical advance, it offers hope for better understanding between experts and laypeople, which is a positive development.
articles.personality_title: Science made clear: how jargon tricks us and how to fix it
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists often wrestle with a tricky choice: should they use complex, technical words that show precision, or simple words that everyone can easily understand? This question is important because it affects how well people grasp scientific ideas.

**What happened**
A new study published in Nature Human Behaviour found that scientific jargon can make explanations sound complete even when they are missing important details. In other words, big fancy words can make weak explanations seem stronger than they really are, which can mislead readers.

**Impact**
This research highlights a challenge in science communication: jargon might impress but confuse or mislead people. Knowing this helps scientists and communicators find better ways to explain ideas clearly and honestly, building trust and understanding with the public.

**What's next step**
Experts can now use these insights to balance accuracy with clarity. By choosing simpler language that still respects scientific facts, they can share knowledge more effectively and help everyone feel confident about science.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Clear, simple language helps science shine brightest by making complex ideas honest and easy to grasp.
articles.personality_title_fr: La science expliquée simplement : comment le jargon nous trompe et comment y remédier
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques doivent souvent choisir entre utiliser des mots techniques précis ou des termes simples que tout le monde comprend facilement. Cette question est importante car elle influence la compréhension des idées scientifiques.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une nouvelle étude publiée dans Nature Human Behaviour a montré que le jargon scientifique peut rendre des explications incomplètes plus convaincantes. En d'autres termes, des mots compliqués peuvent faire paraître une explication faible comme plus solide, ce qui peut induire en erreur.

**Impact**
Cette recherche souligne un défi pour la communication scientifique : le jargon peut impressionner mais aussi embrouiller ou tromper. Comprendre cela aide les scientifiques à mieux expliquer les idées, renforçant la confiance et la compréhension du public.

**Prochaine étape**
Les experts peuvent utiliser ces connaissances pour trouver un équilibre entre précision et clarté. En choisissant un langage simple tout en restant fidèle aux faits scientifiques, ils peuvent partager le savoir plus efficacement et permettre à tous de mieux comprendre la science.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Un langage clair et simple fait briller la science en rendant les idées complexes honnêtes et faciles à comprendre.
articles.personality_title_es: La ciencia clara: cómo el lenguaje técnico nos engaña y cómo solucionarlo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos a menudo enfrentan una difícil decisión: usar palabras técnicas que muestran precisión o palabras simples que todos puedan entender fácilmente. Esta elección es clave para que las personas comprendan bien las ideas científicas.

**Qué pasó**
Un nuevo estudio publicado en Nature Human Behaviour encontró que el lenguaje técnico puede hacer que explicaciones débiles parezcan completas. Es decir, el uso de términos complicados puede hacer que una explicación débil parezca más fuerte de lo que realmente es, lo que puede confundir a los lectores.

**Impacto**
Esta investigación señala un reto en la comunicación científica: el lenguaje técnico puede impresionar pero también confundir o engañar. Saber esto ayuda a científicos y comunicadores a explicar mejor las ideas, generando confianza y entendimiento en el público.

**Próximo paso**
Los expertos ahora pueden usar estos hallazgos para equilibrar precisión y claridad. Al elegir un lenguaje más simple que respete los hechos científicos, pueden compartir el conocimiento de manera más efectiva y ayudar a todos a sentirse seguros con la ciencia.

**Mensaje clave en una frase**
Un lenguaje claro y sencillo hace que la ciencia brille al hacer que las ideas complejas sean honestas y fáciles de entender.
articles.image_prompt: A cozy study scene featuring an open book with two distinct pages: one filled with intricate, swirling scientific symbols and complex patterns, and the other with clear, simple illustrations radiating light; warm, natural tones unify the image, evoking the balance between precise knowledge and accessible understanding.

articles.title: This ancient mega-predator was built for stealth
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 18 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02304-4Fossil evidence suggests that Temnodontosaurus's fore-fin had adaptations to reduce low frequency noise.
articles.content:
You have full access to this article via your institution.

Adaptations for stealth in the wing-like flippers of a large ichthyosaur

The extinct marine mega-predator Temnodontosaurus had specialized adaptations to stealthily hunt its prey, suggests an analysis of a fossil flipper. Temnodontosaurus's lifestyle has been a mystery due to a lack of preserved soft tissue, but fossil remains of a fore-fin have revealed several anatomical details that probably reduced low-frequency noise as the animal swam. The authors suggest that these adaptations show that Temnodontosaurus was a stealth predator.

Hear more on the Nature Podcast.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a scientific discovery about an ancient marine predator's adaptations, contributing to our understanding of prehistoric life. While it is not directly related to human welfare or environmental progress, it is a positive scientific breakthrough that can inspire curiosity and appreciation for natural history.
articles.personality_title: Ancient sea predator built for silent hunting, fossil shows
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Temnodontosaurus was a giant marine predator that lived millions of years ago. Scientists have long wondered how this massive creature hunted its prey in the ocean without being detected.

**What happened**
Recently, researchers studied a fossilized fore-fin of Temnodontosaurus and discovered special features that likely helped it move quietly underwater. These adaptations may have reduced the low-frequency sounds it made, allowing it to sneak up on prey more easily.

**Impact**
This discovery sheds new light on the hunting strategies of ancient sea creatures. Understanding these stealthy adaptations helps scientists appreciate the complexity of prehistoric life and the evolution of marine predators.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to examine more fossils and use advanced technology to learn how widespread these quiet-swimming features were among other extinct marine animals.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A fossil fore-fin reveals how the mighty Temnodontosaurus used built-in stealth to silently hunt in ancient oceans.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un ancien prédateur marin conçu pour chasser en silence, révèle un fossile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le Temnodontosaurus était un grand prédateur marin qui vivait il y a des millions d’années. Les scientifiques se demandaient comment ce gigantesque animal chassait ses proies sans être détecté.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Récemment, des chercheurs ont étudié un fossile de nageoire avant de Temnodontosaurus et ont découvert des caractéristiques spéciales qui l’aidaient probablement à se déplacer silencieusement sous l’eau. Ces adaptations réduisaient les sons graves produits, permettant de surprendre ses proies.

**Impact**
Cette découverte apporte un nouvel éclairage sur les stratégies de chasse des créatures marines anciennes. Elle aide à mieux comprendre la complexité de la vie préhistorique et l’évolution des prédateurs marins.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques veulent étudier d’autres fossiles et utiliser des technologies avancées pour savoir si ces caractéristiques silencieuses étaient courantes chez d’autres animaux marins disparus.

**En une phrase**
Un fossile de nageoire avant révèle comment le puissant Temnodontosaurus utilisait la furtivité intégrée pour chasser silencieusement dans les océans anciens.
articles.personality_title_es: Un antiguo depredador marino construido para cazar en silencio, revela un fósil
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El Temnodontosaurus fue un gran depredador marino que vivió hace millones de años. Los científicos se preguntaban cómo esta enorme criatura cazaba sin ser detectada.

**Qué pasó**
Recientemente, investigadores estudiaron una aleta frontal fosilizada de Temnodontosaurus y encontraron características especiales que probablemente le ayudaban a moverse silenciosamente bajo el agua. Estas adaptaciones reducían los sonidos graves, permitiéndole acechar a sus presas.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento da nueva información sobre las estrategias de caza de criaturas marinas antiguas. Ayuda a entender la complejidad de la vida prehistórica y la evolución de los depredadores marinos.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean examinar más fósiles y usar tecnología avanzada para saber qué tan comunes eran estas características silenciosas en otros animales marinos extintos.

**En una frase**
Una aleta fosilizada revela cómo el poderoso Temnodontosaurus usaba la sigilosidad incorporada para cazar silenciosamente en los océanos antiguos.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a large, sleek ichthyosaur gliding silently underwater with its wing-like flippers subtly glowing to suggest specialized stealth adaptations, surrounded by softly shaded marine life and a calm ocean background in gentle blues and muted earth tones.
